titleInfo.title: Velton P. Guidry oral history interview

mods.abstract: Guidry discusses his family's genealogy and his interest in Cajun genealogy and historical research in general. He tells about his education to the seventh grade, which included corporal punishment, and his Catholic upbringing. His mother worked in a shrimp factory and his father was a fisherman. His large family was somewhat isolated from the poverty of the depression because they grew so much of their own food and his mother was very resourceful. Guidry discusses shrimping as a teenager, trapping, and oystering. He recounts childhood games and beginning to fish at 13. He recalls a childhood vacation to Barataria Bay, which included harvesting bigorneaux (saltwater snails), a visit to Fort Livingston, and encountering an alligator. He recalls working on the water during World War II and seeing submarines and other wartime activity. Guidry also discusses the role of the church in the community (history and physical construction) and in his current life.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.2096. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Joshua Lambert and Stefan Jovicic.

Velton Guidry was born in 1930 and lived in Galliano, Louisiana. He was one of seven children of Gracien and Augusta Choest Guidry. Velton Guidry was married to Gertrude "Gertie" Kiger Guidry, and had two sons, Lenard and Jeffrey. He served in the U.S. Army, was a fisherman since he was 13, and was an amateur genealogist later in life, focusing on local Cajun culture. He was a parishioner at St. Joseph Catholic Church in Galliano and died on May 27, 2011.

physicalDescription.extent: 1 digital audio file (1 hour, 24 minutes); Abstract (5 leaves); Index (7 leaves)

name.namePart: Louisiana State University (Baton Rouge, La.). T. Harry Williams Center for Oral History
